text: hello welcome to bbc world news the
netherlands and denmark are the latest
countries to confirm cases of the new
coronavirus strain omicron as new travel
restrictions are brought in worldwide to
try to limit its spread more than a
fifth of the passengers who tested
positive for covid after returning to
the netherlands from south africa were
carrying the new variant the dutch
authorities have confirmed that 13
people who recently returned on those
flights from south africa have the new
strain out of 61 overall who tested
positive for covet 19. the number of
passengers with omicron could yet rise
as testing isn't completed
scientists fear the highly mutated
variant first detected in southern
africa could be more transmissible and
drive further waves of the disease
the bbc's anna holligan is in amsterdam
with the latest this is a huge concern
because here in the netherlands they're
already battling record-breaking
infection rates and the flights are
still coming in from southern africa so
earlier today there was one from
johannesburg there was another one from
cape town
and yet today new measures are coming
into place here so
bars restaurants cafes non-essential
shops they all have to close by 5 p.m
and this is designed to try to relieve
pressure on the health service the
hospitals are absolutely overwhelmed
with cases already
they're having to cancel operations the
icus are full and there are more than
100 deaths every week as a result of
covet here so huge concerns and this
kind of partial evening lockdown is
coming into force just as so many of the
businesses here in amsterdam the capital
and elsewhere across the country we're
hoping to recover some of the losses
that they've experienced during the
pandemic
